AbstractText.sentence: BACKGROUND: Adhesion molecule expression on the endothelial cell (EC) surface is critical for leukocyte recruitment to atherosclerotic lesions.

AbstractText.sentence: Better understanding of transcriptional regulation of adhesion molecules in ECs may provide important insight into plaque formation.

event.clue: Better understanding of transcriptional regulation of adhesion molecules in ECs may provide important insight into plaque formation.

AbstractText.sentence: Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPARalpha), a member of the nuclear receptor family, regulates gene expression in response to certain fatty acids and fibric acid derivatives.

AbstractText.sentence: The present study investigated PPARalpha expression in human ECs and their regulation of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1).

event.clue: The present study investigated PPARalpha expression in human ECs and their regulation of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1).

AbstractText.sentence: METHODS AND RESULTS: Immunohistochemistry revealed that human carotid artery ECs express PPARalpha.

event.clue: METHODS AND RESULTS: Immunohistochemistry revealed that human carotid artery ECs express PPARalpha.

AbstractText.sentence: Pretreatment of cultured human ECs with the PPARalpha activators fenofibrate or WY14643 inhibited TNF-alpha-induced VCAM-1 in a time- and concentration-dependent manner, an effect not seen with PPARgamma activators.

event.clue: Pretreatment of cultured human ECs with the PPARalpha activators fenofibrate or WY14643 inhibited TNF-alpha-induced VCAM-1 in a time- and concentration-dependent manner, an effect not seen with PPARgamma activators.

AbstractText.sentence: Transient transfection of deletional VCAM-1 promoter constructs and electrophoretic mobility shift assays suggest that fenofibrate inhibits VCAM-1 transcription in part by inhibiting NF-kappaB.

AbstractText.sentence: Such findings also have implications regarding the clinical use of lipid-lowering agents, like fibric acids, which can activate PPARalpha.
